awd_abstract_narration:
The workshop brings together researchers at the intersection of technology and economics to help understand the large technical trends that are changing how computing is done, how these trends are evolving, and what this will mean for the benefits provided to society.  Participants include both those interested in the microeconomics of technology and those interested in the technological foundations of prosperity and economic growth.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Progress in information technology has been responsible for a large share of U.S. productivity growth in recent decades, generating trillions of dollars in U.S. GDP. Nevertheless, the last 10+ years have brought enormous change in computing, for example, as Dennard Scaling ended and Moore’s Law faded. At the same time, there is unprecedented interest in AI and robotics and their potential role in shaping the economy’s future.

The goal of the conference was to bring together researchers at the intersection of technology and economics to help understand how these trends are evolving and what they will mean for the benefits provided to society. Through gathering experts in economics and computer science, this conference aimed to explore how progress in computing translates into greater economic prosperity. Specifically, the conference sought to understand: 1) what are the significant sources of progress in computing? 2) how are they changing? 3) how much impact does this progress have? The major goal of the conference is to create a cross-disciplinary community with computer scientists and economists to articulate a research agenda for the community.

On Sept 30-Oct 1, 2022 the conference brought together experts in economics and computer science to explore how progress in computing translates into greater economic prosperity.  Those part of this discussion included 16 expert speakers and about 50 other attendees.

The conference gathered opinions on the state of (1) Moore’s law and progress in computing. (2) Automation/Augmentation of Work; (3) The Next Stage of Computer Progress; and (4) Artificial Intelligence.

Session 1: Moore’s law and progress in computing

In session 1: Moore’s law and progress in computing, four speakers extensively discussed the end of Moore’s law and the semiconductor industry’s evolution and examined the impact of IT on the economy. As Charles Leiserson and Dan Armbrust both highlighted, we are at the very end of Moore’s law; the physical limit of semiconductors’ foundation (silicon lattice) is challenging the development of computation and even society. Therefore, it is time to explore future computational directions to boost productivity for the post-Moore Era. In addition, as Gilbert Cette and Kristina McElheran both stressed, economists are still seeking to resolve the long-standing Solow productivity paradox. “the computer age was everywhere except for the productivity statistics.” McElheran presented reasons why this could be partially explained by a lag in complementary investments and adaptation (akin to factory adjustments after electrification), and Cette highlighted the long time lag between the digital revolution and the economic impact (especially in services) at the macro level. 

Session 2: Automation/augmentation of work

In session 2: automation/augmentation of work, four speakers extensively discussed the progress of robots and automation in science and industry and the impact of adopting robots on the labor market.

As suggested by David Autor, the crucial question is to identify which kinds of work will be automated and replaced by technology and which work will be augmented, making humans more productive, and potentially creating new employment.  Alex Shikany reported seeing these employment benefits in real-world deployments of robots, and Rob Seamans stressed that microeconomic analyses have been ambiguous about job creation.  Whereas for firm productivity, there is some evidence of improvement but it may require having the right complementary service companies available locally. Improving these estimates will require better economic models of the causal effect of robots on the economy and better data for answering these questions.

Kathy Yelick also highlighted that collaboration with computer scientists will be important for better answering key science questions, e.g. on climate change issues.

Session 3: the next stage of computer progress

In session 3: the next stage of computer progress, four speakers extensively discussed potential directions for computing, such as high-performance computing/supercomputing as indicated by both Mark Rosker and John Shalf, hardware specialization as pointed out by Adi Fuchs, quantum computing as discussed by Mark Horowitz. All four highlighted potential for improvement, they also agreed pointed to the limits of those technologies and their upside potential – leaving open the question of where the next Moore’s Law-like gains could come from.

Session 4: Artificial Intelligence

In session 4: Artificial Intelligence, four speakers extensively discussed the development of AI (profound learning) and its impacts on the economy and society. Hooker and Strubell emphasized the computational and environmental burden of deep learning, and how deep learning has won the ‘hardware lottery’ by being well adapted to parallel implementations, like GPUs.  Parashar echoed this importance and discussed the creation of a public resource to provide massive computing power.  Despite these gains, Jones highlighted that arguments such as Baumol’s cost disease could prevent AI progress from turning into large, sustained productivity or economic gains.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 03/05/2023
Modified by: Neil Thompson
